Award.AwardTitle: Montana Tribal College Faculty Professional Development Workshop

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the STEM instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the STEM curricular offerings at these institutions expands the opportunities of their students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be culturally significant, and encourages a community and generational appreciation for science and mathematics education. The focus of the proposal from the University of Montana (UM) is on developing faculty at Tribal instituions,so they too will be able to support the needs of their students. In addition, through a pilot workshop UM hopes to build collaborative efforts with the Montana tribal colleges,which could provide more opportunities for tribal students to do research at UM.

The University of Montana will conduct a pilot professional development workshop for Montana tribal college faculty, and establish partnerships among the seven Montana tribal colleges and UM. Addressing a request of Montana tribal college (TC) faculty for professional development, the Montana Tribal College Faculty Professional Development Workshop will host tribal college faculty members on the UM campus to investigate innovative instructional and research practices while also building a collaboration network among the TC faculty and UM faculty mentors. The workshop will divide TC faculty into research groups each working with a UM faculty member. The groups will investigate laboratory research practices that are appropriate for the TC's campus laboratory infrastructures, the needs of their students, and the knowledge, skills, and abilities of the TC faculty members. The research group model will yield a faculty network, as TC faculty learn from each other and the UM faculty partners for future research discussions and collaborations. The justification and design of the workshop is based upon recent visits to each of Montana's tribal colleges. TC faculty consistently described limitations to research practices largely inherent to their teaching demands. Commonly, TC faculty expressed the limitation in instructing large numbers of classes each semester that lead to little time for incorporating new and novel curriculum development and research into their classrooms. The time restrictions also limit their networking with collaborators and fellow TC faculty on other TC campuses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The "Montana Tribal College Faculty Professional Development Workshop" had the following major outcomes:

1. Built a Community of Practice: The seven tribal colleges on seven reservations in Montana are all located in rural areas. In addition to the geographic isolation, faculty members from these colleges have heavy teaching loads and have rare opportunities to connect and communicate with faculty members from other institutions. Through the participation of the one-week workshop at the University of Montana (UM) and two follow up meetings (one at Bozeman and the other at Great Falls), the workshop had a broad impact on the 8 participants from five tribal colleges as they developed strong relationships and connections, both professionally and personally. Learning and collaborations occur within such community. Avenues of communication between faculty of the tribal college were established that lead to several collabroative efforts.  For instance, at the workshop, the math faculty members from Stone Child College, Salish Kootenai College, and Aaniiih Nakoda discovered that they all have similar challenges with their current math placement test. Thus they worked together to develop a common math placement test. 

2. Introduced new research avenues, resources, and opportunities for collaboration:  The 8 tribal college faculty representing 5 of the Montana Tribal Colleges were immersed in lab experiences with faculty from the University of Montana.  This allowed the tribal college faculty to be introduced to new research areas and resources as part of the intellectual merit of the program. For instance, the faculty member from Blackfeet Community College worked with one faculty at U of MT during the workshop in last summer and she returned back in this summer and continued her research at this faculty’s lab. Another example is that the three tribal college math faculty members identified the lack of professional development (PD) opportunities for K-12 math teachers on or near their reservations. They wrote a proposal to provide summer PD workshops for their local math teachers and the proposal was funded by the Montana Office of Commissioner of Higher Education. Another product from this project is that at one the follow up meetings the whole group of tribal college faculty participants expressed mutual interest in future collaboration, identified opportunities for such collaboration, and are currently working on a proposal for a tribal college faculty exchange program.
